entry.title: Geometry of Hilbert Spaces
entry.content:
Definition. If M\mathcal{M}M is a subset of the Hilbert space H\mathscr{H}H, then the orthogonal complement of M\mathcal{M}M, denoted M⊥\mathcal{M}^{\perp}M⊥,is the set of vectors in H\mathscr{H}H orthogonal every vector in M\mathcal{M}M.

Remark. M⊥\mathcal{M}^{\perp}M⊥ is a closed subspaces of H\mathscr{H}H.

Proof. Let xxx,yyy ∈M⊥\in \mathscr{M}^{\perp}∈M⊥, ∀z∈M\forall z \in \mathcal{M}∀z∈M, <z,x>=<z,y>=0<{z},{x}> = <{z},{y}> = 0<z,x>=<z,y>=0. Then,

<z,x+y>=<z,x>+<z,y>=0+0=0.<{z},{x+y}> = <{z},{x}> + <{z},{y}> = 0+0 = 0.<z,x+y>=<z,x>+<z,y>=0+0=0.

This implies x+y∈M⊥x+y \in \mathscr{M}^{\perp}x+y∈M⊥. And ∀λ∈C\forall \lambda \in \mathbb{C}∀λ∈C, <λz,x>=0<{\lambda z},{x}> = 0<λz,x>=0, then λz∈M⊥\lambda z \in \mathscr{M}^{\perp}λz∈M⊥. Hence, M⊥\mathscr{M}^{\perp}M⊥ is a subspace of H\mathscr{H}H.

Next, we only need to show M⊥\mathscr{M}^{\perp}M⊥ is closed. For x∈Mx \in \mathcal{M}x∈M, we can define a linear functional φx(z):=<z,x>\varphi_x(z) := <{z},{x}>φx​(z):=<z,x>, themM⊥=⋂x∈MKerφx\mathscr{M}^{\perp} = \bigcap_{x \in \mathcal{M}} \textbf{Ker}{\varphi_{x}}M⊥=⋂x∈M​Kerφx​ is a closed subset of H\mathscr{H}H. ◻

Theorem. If M\mathcal{M}M is a closed subspace of the Hilbert space H\mathscr{H}H and f∈Hf \in \mathscr{H}f∈H, then there exist unique vectors g∈Mg \in \mathcal{M}g∈M and h∈M⊥h \in \mathscr{M}^{\perp}h∈M⊥ such that

f=g+h.f = g + h.f=g+h.

Proof. Set K={f−k:k∈M}\mathscr{K} = \{f - k: k \in \mathcal{M}\}K={f−k:k∈M}, then K\mathscr{K}K is a nonempty, closed and convex subset of H\mathscr{H}H.
Hence, there exists the unique element h∈Kh \in \mathscr{K}h∈K with the smallest norm. Consider k∈Mk \in \mathcal{M}k∈M, then h−<h,k>k∈Kh - <{h},{k}>k \in \mathscr{K}h−<h,k>k∈K, and hence

∥h∥2≤∥h−<h,k>k∥2=∥h∥2−<h,k>‾<h,k>−<h,k><h,k>‾+<h,k><h,k>‾∥k∥2.\begin{aligned}{\|{h}\|}^2 &\le {\|{h - <{h},{k}>k}{}\|}^2 \\&= \|{h}{}\|^2 - \overline{<{h},{k}>} <{h},{k}> - <{h},{k}>\overline{<{h},{k}>} + <{h},{k}>\overline{<{h},{k}>}{\|{k}{}\|}^2.\end{aligned}∥h∥2​≤∥h−<h,k>k∥2=∥h∥2−<h,k>​<h,k>−<h,k><h,k>​+<h,k><h,k>​∥k∥2.​

Therefore, we have ∣<h,k>∣2≤0|{<{h},{k}>}|^2 \le 0∣<h,k>∣2≤0, which implies <h,k>=0<{h},{k}> = 0<h,k>=0, h∈M⊥h\in \mathscr{M}^{\perp}h∈M⊥. Since h∈Kh \in \mathscr{K}h∈K, then ∃g∈M\exists g \in \mathcal{M}∃g∈M, such that f=g+hf = g+hf=g+h.

Uniqueness: If f=g1+h1=g2+h2f = g_1 + h_1 = g_2 + h_2f=g1​+h1​=g2​+h2​, with g1,g2∈Mg_1, g_2 \in \mathcal{M}g1​,g2​∈M, and h1,h2∈M⊥h_1, h_2 \in \mathscr{M}^{\perp}h1​,h2​∈M⊥. Then g1−g2=h1−h2∈M⋂M⊥g_1 - g_2 = h_1 - h_2 \in \mathcal{M} \bigcap \mathscr{M}^{\perp}g1​−g2​=h1​−h2​∈M⋂M⊥. This means that (g1−g2)⊥(g1−g2)(g_1 - g_2) \perp (g_1 - g_2)(g1​−g2​)⊥(g1​−g2​), and (h1−h2)⊥(h1−h2)(h_1 - h_2) \perp (h_1 - h_2)(h1​−h2​)⊥(h1​−h2​). <g1−g2,g1−g2>=<h1−h2,h1−h2>=∥g1−g2∥2=∥h1−h2∥2=0.<{g_1 - g_2},{g_1 - g_2}> = <{h_1 - h_2}, {h_1 - h_2}> = \|{g_1 - g_2}{}\|^2 = \|{h_1 - h_2}{}\|^2 = 0.<g1​−g2​,g1​−g2​>=<h1​−h2​,h1​−h2​>=∥g1​−g2​∥2=∥h1​−h2​∥2=0.
Then g1=g2g_1 = g_2g1​=g2​ and h1=h2h_1 = h_2h1​=h2​. ◻

Corollory. If M\mathcal{M}M is a subspace of the Hilbert space H\mathscr{H}H, then M⊥⊥=M‾\mathcal{M}^{\perp \perp} = \overline{\mathcal{M}}M⊥⊥=M.

Proof. Obvious that M⊂M⊥⊥\mathcal{M} \subset \mathcal{M}^{\perp \perp}M⊂M⊥⊥(By definition of M⊥\mathscr{M}^{\perp}M⊥). Hence, M‾⊂M⊥⊥\overline{\mathcal{M}} \subset \mathcal{M}^{\perp \perp}M⊂M⊥⊥.
Iff∈M⊥⊥f \in \mathcal{M}^{\perp \perp}f∈M⊥⊥, then f=g+hf = g + hf=g+h, where g∈M‾g \in \overline{\mathcal{M}}g∈M, and h∈M⊥h \in \mathscr{M}^{\perp}h∈M⊥. Since f∈M⊥⊥f \in \mathcal{M}^{\perp \perp}f∈M⊥⊥, we have

0=<f,h>=<g+h,h>=<h,h>=∥h∥2.0 = <{f},{h}> = <{g+h},{h}> = <{h},{h}> = \|{h}{}\|^2.0=<f,h>=<g+h,h>=<h,h>=∥h∥2.

Therefore, h=0h = 0h=0, hence, f∈M‾f \in \overline{M}f∈M. ◻

Theorem. If φ\varphiφ is a bounded linear functional on H\mathscr{H}H, then there
exists a unique g∈Hg \in \mathscr{H}g∈H such that φ(f)=<f,g>\varphi(f) = <{f},{g}>φ(f)=<f,g> for f∈Hf \in \mathscr{H}f∈H.

Proof. Let K=Kerφ={f∈H:φ(f)=0}\mathscr{K} = \textbf{Ker} \varphi = \{f \in \mathscr{H} : \varphi(f) = 0\}K=Kerφ={f∈H:φ(f)=0}. Since φ\varphiφ is continuous, K\mathscr{K}K is a closed subspace of H\mathscr{H}H. If K=H\mathscr{K} = \mathscr{H}K=H, then φ(f)=<f,0>\varphi(f) = <{f},{0}>φ(f)=<f,0>, ∀f∈H\forall f \in \mathscr{H}∀f∈H.

If K⊊H\mathscr{K} \subsetneq \mathscr{H}K⊊H, then ∃h∈K⊥\exists h \in \mathscr{K}^{\perp}∃h∈K⊥ with ∥h∥=1\|{h}{}\| = 1∥h∥=1. Since h∉Kh \notin \mathscr{K}h∈/​K, then φ(h)≠0\varphi(h) \neq 0φ(h)​=0.

Since

φ(f−φ(f)φ(h)h)=φ(f)−φ(f)φ(h)φ(h)=0,∀f∈H.\varphi(f - \frac{\varphi(f)}{\varphi(h)} h) = \varphi(f) - \frac{\varphi(f)}{\varphi(h)}\varphi(h) = 0, \quad \forall f \in \mathscr{H}.φ(f−φ(h)φ(f)​h)=φ(f)−φ(h)φ(f)​φ(h)=0,∀f∈H.

Then ∀f∈H\forall f \in \mathscr{H}∀f∈H, f−φ(f)φ(h)h∈Kf - \frac{\varphi(f)}{\varphi(h)} h \in \mathscr{K}f−φ(h)φ(f)​h∈K. Therefore, for
f∈Hf\in \mathscr{H}f∈H, we have

φ(f)=φ(f)<h,h>=<φ(f)φ(h)h,φ(h)‾h>=<φ(f)φ(h)h,φ(h)‾h>+<f−φ(f)φ(h)h,φ(h)‾h>=<f,φ(h)‾h>.\begin{aligned} \varphi(f) &= \varphi(f)<{h},{h}> = <{\frac{\varphi(f)}{\varphi(h)} h },{\overline{\varphi(h)} h }> \\ &= <{\frac{\varphi(f)}{\varphi(h)} h },{\overline{\varphi(h)} h }> + <{f - \frac{\varphi(f)}{\varphi(h)} h},{\overline{\varphi(h)} h}> \\ &= <{f},{\overline{\varphi(h)}h}>.\end{aligned}φ(f)​=φ(f)<h,h>=<φ(h)φ(f)​h,φ(h)​h>=<φ(h)φ(f)​h,φ(h)​h>+<f−φ(h)φ(f)​h,φ(h)​h>=<f,φ(h)​h>.​

Uniqueness: If <f,g1>=<f,g2><{f},{g_1}> = <{f},{g_2}><f,g1​>=<f,g2​>
∀f∈H\forall f \in \mathscr{H}∀f∈H, then <g1−g2,g1−g2>=0<{g_1 - g_2},{g_1 - g_2}> = 0<g1​−g2​,g1​−g2​>=0,
g1=g2g_1 = g_2g1​=g2​. ◻

Theorem. If {fα}α∈Λ\{f_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in \Lambda}{fα​}α∈Λ​ is an orthogonal subset of Hilbert space H\mathscr{H}H, then ∑α∈Λfα\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} f_{\alpha}∑α∈Λ​fα​ converges if and only if ∑α∈Λ∥fα∥2<+∞\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 < +\infty∑α∈Λ​∥fα​∥2<+∞. And in this case, we have

∥∑α∈Λfα∥2=∑α∈Λ∥fα∥2.\|{\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 = \sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda}\|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2.∥α∈Λ∑​fα​∥2=α∈Λ∑​∥fα​∥2.

Back to the definition of arbitrary sum:

Definition. Let {fα}α∈A\{f_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}{fα​}α∈A​ be a set of vectors in the Banache space XXX. Let F={F⊂A:F is finite}\mathscr{F} = \{F \subset A : F \text{ is finite}\}F={F⊂A:F is finite}. If we define F1≤F2F_1 \le F_2F1​≤F2​ for F1⊂F2F_1 \subset F_2F1​⊂F2​, then F\mathscr{F}F is a directed set(also means the partial ordered set). For each F∈FF \in \mathscr{F}F∈F, let gF=∑α∈Ffαg_F = \sum_{\alpha \in F} f_{\alpha}gF​=∑α∈F​fα​. If the net {gF}F∈F\{g_F\}_{F \in \mathscr{F}}{gF​}F∈F​ converges to some ggg in XXX, then the sum ∑α∈Afα\sum_{\alpha \in A} f_{\alpha}∑α∈A​fα​ is said to converge and we write g=∑α∈Afαg = \sum_{\alpha \in A}f_{\alpha}g=∑α∈A​fα​.

Proof. Consider a finite subset F⊂ΛF \subset \LambdaF⊂Λ, then, we have

∥∑α∈Ffα∥2=∑α∈F∥fα∥2.\|{\sum_{\alpha \in F} f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 = \sum_{\alpha \in F} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2.∥α∈F∑​fα​∥2=α∈F∑​∥fα​∥2.

Let F\mathscr{F}F denote the collection of finite subsets of Λ\LambdaΛ. If ∑α∈Λfα\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} f_{\alpha}∑α∈Λ​fα​ converges, then

∥∑α∈Λfα∥2=∥lim⁡F∈F∑α∈Ffα∥2=lim⁡F∈F∥∑α∈Ffα∥2=lim⁡F∈F∑α∈F∥fα∥2=∑α∈Λ∥fα∥2.\begin{aligned} \|{\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 &= \|{\lim_{F \in \mathscr{F}} \sum_{\alpha \in F} f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 = \lim_{F \in \mathscr{F}} \|{\sum_{\alpha \in F} f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 \\ &= \lim_{F \in \mathscr{F}}\sum_{\alpha \in F} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 = \sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2.\end{aligned}∥α∈Λ∑​fα​∥2​=∥F∈Flim​α∈F∑​fα​∥2=F∈Flim​∥α∈F∑​fα​∥2=F∈Flim​α∈F∑​∥fα​∥2=α∈Λ∑​∥fα​∥2.​

Hence, if ∑α∈Λfα\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} f_{\alpha}∑α∈Λ​fα​ convergers, then ∑α∈Λ∥fα∥2<∞\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 < \infty∑α∈Λ​∥fα​∥2<∞.

Conversely, if ∑α∈Λ∥fα∥2<∞\sum_{\alpha \in \Lambda} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 < \infty∑α∈Λ​∥fα​∥2<∞. ∀ε>0\forall \varepsilon > 0∀ε>0, ∃F0∈F\exists F_0 \in \mathscr{F}∃F0​∈F such that F≥F0F \ge F_0F≥F0​ implies ∑α∈F∥fα∥2−∑α∈F0∥fα∥2<ε2\sum_{\alpha \in F} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 - \sum_{\alpha \in F_0} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 < \varepsilon^2∑α∈F​∥fα​∥2−∑α∈F0​​∥fα​∥2<ε2.
Thus, for F1,F2∈FF_1,F_2 \in \mathscr{F}F1​,F2​∈F such that F1,F2≥F0F_1, F_2 \ge F_0F1​,F2​≥F0​, we have

∥∑α∈F1fα−∑α∈F2fα∥2=∑α∈F1\F2∥fα∥2+∑α∈F2\F1∥fα∥2≤∑α∈F1∪F2∥fα∥2−∑α∈F0∥fα∥2<ε2.\begin{aligned} \|{\sum_{\alpha \in F_1} f_{\alpha} - \sum_{\alpha \in F_2} f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 &= \sum_{\alpha \in F_1 \backslash F_2} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 + \sum_{\alpha \in F_2 \backslash F_1 } \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 \\ &\le \sum_{\alpha \in F_1 \cup F_2} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 - \sum_{\alpha \in F_0} \|{f_{\alpha}}{}\|^2 < \varepsilon^2.\end{aligned}∥α∈F1​∑​fα​−α∈F2​∑​fα​∥2​=α∈F1​\F2​∑​∥fα​∥2+α∈F2​\F1​∑​∥fα​∥2≤α∈F1​∪F2​∑​∥fα​∥2−α∈F0​∑​∥fα​∥2<ε2.​

Hence, the net {∑α∈Ffα}F∈F\{\sum_{\alpha \in F} f_{\alpha}\}_{F \in \mathscr{F}}{∑α∈F​fα​}F∈F​ is Cauchy in H\mathscr{H}H, which is convergence. ◻

Corollary. If {eα}α∈A\{e_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}{eα​}α∈A​ is an orthonormal subset of the Hilbert space H\mathscr{H}H and M\mathcal{M}M is the smallest closed subspace of H\mathscr{H}H containing the set {eα:α∈A}\{e_{\alpha} : \alpha \in A\}{eα​:α∈A}, then

M={∑α∈Aλαeα:λα∈C,∑α∈A∣λα∣2<∞}.\mathcal{M} = \left\{\sum_{\alpha \in A} \lambda_{\alpha} e_{\alpha }: \lambda_{\alpha} \in \mathbb{C} , \sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\lambda_{\alpha}}|^2 < \infty\right\}.M={α∈A∑​λα​eα​:λα​∈C,α∈A∑​∣λα​∣2<∞}.

Proof. Let N={∑α∈Aλαeα:λα∈C,∑α∈A∣λα∣2<∞}\mathcal{N} = \left\{\sum_{\alpha \in A} \lambda_{\alpha} e_{\alpha }: \lambda_{\alpha} \in \mathbb{C} , \sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\lambda_{\alpha}}|^2 < \infty\right\}N={∑α∈A​λα​eα​:λα​∈C,∑α∈A​∣λα​∣2<∞}. We have N⊂M\mathcal{N} \subset \mathcal{M}N⊂M.
Then, we only need to show N\mathcal{N}N is a closed subspace of H\mathscr{H}H containing the set {eα}α∈A\{e_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}{eα​}α∈A​.

Step 1. We prove that N\mathcal{N}N is a closed subspace of H\mathscr{H}H containing the set {eα:α∈A}\{e_{\alpha} : \alpha \in A\}{eα​:α∈A}.

Assume {λα}α∈A,{μα}α∈A\{\lambda_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}, \{\mu_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}{λα​}α∈A​,{μα​}α∈A​ satisfy ∑α∈A∣λα∣2<∞\sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\lambda_{\alpha}}|^2 < \infty∑α∈A​∣λα​∣2<∞ and ∑α∈A∣μα∣2<∞\sum_{\alpha \in A } |{\mu_{\alpha}}|^2 < \infty∑α∈A​∣μα​∣2<∞, then

∑α∈A∣λα+μα∣2≤∑α∈A2(∣λα∣2+∣μα∣2)=2∑α∈A∣λα∣2+2∑α∈A∣μα∣2<∞.\begin{aligned}\sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\lambda_{\alpha}+ \mu_{\alpha}}|^2 &\le \sum_{\alpha \in A} 2(|{\lambda_{\alpha}}|^2 + |{\mu_{\alpha}}|^2)\\&= 2\sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\lambda_{\alpha}}|^2 + 2 \sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\mu_{\alpha}}|^2 < \infty.\end{aligned}α∈A∑​∣λα​+μα​∣2​≤α∈A∑​2(∣λα​∣2+∣μα​∣2)=2α∈A∑​∣λα​∣2+2α∈A∑​∣μα​∣2<∞.​

This implies ∑α∈Aλαeα+∑α∈Aμαeα=∑α∈A(λα+μα)eα∈N\sum_{\alpha \in A} \lambda_{\alpha}e_{\alpha} + \sum_{\alpha \in A} \mu_{\alpha}e_{\alpha} = \sum_{\alpha \in A}(\lambda_{\alpha} + \mu_{\alpha})e_{\alpha} \in \mathcal{N}∑α∈A​λα​eα​+∑α∈A​μα​eα​=∑α∈A​(λα​+μα​)eα​∈N. and it is easy to verify that ∑α∈Aaλαeα∈N\sum_{\alpha \in A} a \lambda_{\alpha}e_{\alpha} \in \mathcal{N}∑α∈A​aλα​eα​∈N for all a∈Ca \in \mathbb{C}a∈C and eα∈N,∀α∈Ae_{\alpha} \in \mathcal{N}, \forall \alpha \in Aeα​∈N,∀α∈A.

Step 2. We prove that N\mathcal{N}N is closed and N⊂M\mathcal{N} \subset \mathcal{M}N⊂M.

Note that N=ℓ2(A)\mathcal{N} = \ell^2(A)N=ℓ2(A) actually. Then N\mathcal{N}N is closed. ◻

Definition. A subset {eα}α∈A\{e_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}{eα​}α∈A​ of the Hilbert space H\mathscr{H}H is said to be an orthonormal basis if it is orthonormal and the smallest closed subspace containing it is H\mathscr{H}H.

Corollary. If {eα}α∈A\{e_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}{eα​}α∈A​ is an orthonormal basis for the Hilbert space H\mathscr{H}H and f∈Hf \in \mathscr{H}f∈H, then there is a unique Fourier coefficients {λα}α∈A\{\lambda_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}{λα​}α∈A​ contained in C\mathbb{C}C such that f=∑α∈Aλαeαf = \sum_{\alpha \in A} \lambda _{\alpha}e_{\alpha}f=∑α∈A​λα​eα​. Moreover, λα=<f,eα>\lambda_{\alpha} = <{f},{e_{\alpha}}>λα​=<f,eα​> for α∈A\alpha \in Aα∈A.

Proof. By Corollary above we have

H={∑α∈Aλαeα:λα∈C,∑α∈A∣λα∣2<∞}.\mathscr{H} = \left\{\sum_{\alpha \in A} \lambda_{\alpha} e_{\alpha} : \lambda_{\alpha} \in \mathbb{C}, \sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\lambda_{\alpha}}|^2 < \infty\right\}.H={α∈A∑​λα​eα​:λα​∈C,α∈A∑​∣λα​∣2<∞}.

Hence, ∀f∈H\forall f \in \mathscr{H}∀f∈H, there is {λα}\{\lambda_{\alpha}\}{λα​}, with ∑α∈A∣λα∣2<∞\sum_{\alpha \in A} |{\lambda_{\alpha}}|^2 < \infty∑α∈A​∣λα​∣2<∞, such that f=∑α∈Aλαeαf = \sum_{\alpha \in A} \lambda_{\alpha}e_{\alpha}f=∑α∈A​λα​eα​. Then, we only need to show the uniqueness.

If f=∑α∈Aλαeα=∑α∈Aμαeαf = \sum_{\alpha \in A} \lambda_{\alpha} e_{\alpha} = \sum_{\alpha \in A}\mu_{\alpha}e_{\alpha}f=∑α∈A​λα​eα​=∑α∈A​μα​eα​. Then 0=∑α∈A(λα−μα)eα0 = \sum_{\alpha \in A}(\lambda_{\alpha} - \mu_{\alpha})e_{\alpha}0=∑α∈A​(λα​−μα​)eα​.
Hence for each β∈A\beta \in Aβ∈A,

0=<0,eβ>=<∑α∈A(λα−μα),eα>eβ=∑α∈A(λα−μα)<eα,eβ>=λβ−μβ.\begin{aligned}0 &= <{0},{e_{\beta}}> \\&= <{\sum_{\alpha \in A}(\lambda_{\alpha} - \mu_{\alpha}),e_{\alpha}}>{e_{\beta}}\\&= \sum_{\alpha \in A}(\lambda_{\alpha} - \mu_{\alpha})<{e_{\alpha}},{e_{\beta}}>\\&= \lambda_{\beta} - \mu_{\beta}.\end{aligned}0​=<0,eβ​>=<α∈A∑​(λα​−μα​),eα​>eβ​=α∈A∑​(λα​−μα​)<eα​,eβ​>=λβ​−μβ​.​

Hence, λβ=μβ\lambda_{\beta} = \mu_{\beta}λβ​=μβ​, ∀β∈A\forall \beta \in A∀β∈A.

Finally for each β∈A\beta \in Aβ∈A,

<{f},{e_{\beta}}> = \sum_{\alpha \in A}\lambda_{\alpha}<{e_{\alpha}},{e_{\beta}}> = \lambda_{\beta}.$$ ◻*Theorem.* Every Hilbert space() possesses an orthonormal basis.*Proof.* Since , then has at least one orthonormal set. Assume, denoted by the collection of all orthonormal subsets of . And define the ordered on , for , if . Then is a partial ordered set.Let is a total ordered subset of , let .We prove is an orthonormal subsets of , hence it is an upper bound of , there is , such that and . Since, is total ordered, then . Then, and (Since ).Hence, let , then is an orthonormal subsets of containing , which contradicts with is maximal.Thus, , is an orthonormal basis of . ◻*Theorem.* If and are orthonormal basis for the Hilbert space , then .*Proof.* If , then, there is a injective map from into a proper subset of .Then, , and is an orthonormal subset of . Let . Then, , and choose .For each ,

\tau(e_{\gamma}) = \sum_{\alpha \in A} <{\tau(e_{\gamma})},{e_{\alpha}}>e_{\alpha}.

Then can extend to a linear map on . is one-to-one and onto by define

\tau(x) = \sum_{\gamma \in A}<{x},{e_{\gamma}}>\tau(e_{\gamma}), \quad \forall x \in \mathscr{H}.$$
τ\tauτ is continuous.

If the claim holds, we have τ−1\tau^{-1}τ−1 is continuous. Then Span‾A=Span‾C\overline{\textbf{Span}}A = \overline{\textbf{Span}}CSpan​A=Span​C, K=H\mathcal{K} = \mathscr{H}K=H. This is contradiction!

Hence, #A≥#B\#A \ge \#B#A≥#B, by symmetry #B≥#A\#B \ge \#A#B≥#A. #A=#B\#A = \#B#A=#B.

Finally, we prove the claim

Assume x∈Hx \in \mathscr{H}x∈H, ∥x∥=1\|{x}\| = 1∥x∥=1. Then,

∥τ(x)∥2=∥∑γ∈A<x,eγ>τ(eγ)∥2=∑γ∈A∣<x,eγ>∣2=∥x∥2.\|{\tau(x)}{}\|^2 = \|{\sum_{\gamma \in A} <{x},{e_{\gamma}}> \tau(e_{\gamma})}{}\|^2 = \sum_{\gamma \in A}|{<{x},{e_{\gamma}}>}|^2 = \|{x}{}\|^2.∥τ(x)∥2=∥γ∈A∑​<x,eγ​>τ(eγ​)∥2=γ∈A∑​∣<x,eγ​>∣2=∥x∥2.

Hence, τ\tauτ is continuous. We complete the proof. ◻

Theorem. If H\mathscr{H}H is a Hilbert space, then the dimension of H\mathscr{H}H, denoted dim⁡H\dim \mathscr{H}dimH, is the cardinality of any orthonormal basis for H\mathscr{H}H.

Theorem. Two Hilbert spaces are isomorphic if and only if their dimensions are equal.

Example. Cn\mathbb{C}^nCn with inner product z=(z1,z2,⋯ ,zn)z = (z_1, z_2, \cdots, z_n)z=(z1​,z2​,⋯,zn​), w=(w1,w2,⋯ ,wn)∈Cnw = (w_1, w_2,\cdots, w_n) \in \mathbb{C}^nw=(w1​,w2​,⋯,wn​)∈Cn, then

<z,w>=∑k=1nzkwk‾.<{z},{w}> = \sum_{k=1}^{n}z_k \overline{w_k}.<z,w>=k=1∑n​zk​wk​​.

and {ek=(0,⋯ ,0,1,0,⋯ ,0)}k=1n\{e_k = (0,\cdots, 0, 1, 0, \cdots, 0)\}_{k = 1}^{n}{ek​=(0,⋯,0,1,0,⋯,0)}k=1n​ is the orthonormal basis of Cn\mathbb{C}^nCn. Then dim⁡Cn=n\dim \mathbb{C}^n = ndimCn=n.

Theorem. ℓ2(Z+)\ell^2(\mathbb{Z}^+)ℓ2(Z+) with inner product f,g∈ℓ2(Z+)f, g \in \ell^2(\mathbb{Z}^+)f,g∈ℓ2(Z+), then

<f,g>=∑n=1∞f(n)g(n)‾.<{f},{g}> = \sum_{n = 1}^{\infty} f(n)\overline{g(n)}.<f,g>=n=1∑∞​f(n)g(n)​.

and consider {en}n∈Z+\{e_n\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}^+}{en​}n∈Z+​, where en(m)=δn,me_n(m) = \delta_{n,m}en​(m)=δn,m​. Which is an orthonormal basis of ℓ2(Z+)\ell^2(\mathbb{Z}^+)ℓ2(Z+). Hence, dim⁡ℓ2(Z+)=ℵ0\dim \ell^2(\mathbb{Z}^+) = \aleph_0dimℓ2(Z+)=ℵ0​.

Theorem. In the Hilbert space L2([0,1])L^2([0,1])L2([0,1]), the set {e2πinx}n∈Z\{e^{2\pi i n x}\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}{e2πinx}n∈Z​ is orthonormal since

∫01e2πi(m−n)xdx={1,m=n0,m≠n\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1} e^{2\pi i (m-n) x}dx =\left\{\begin{matrix} 1,& m=n\\ 0,& m\neq n \end{matrix}\right.\end{aligned}∫01​e2πi(m−n)xdx={1,0,​m=nm​=n​​

By Stone-Weierstrass theorem,Span‾∥⋅∥∞{e2πinx}n∈Z=C([0,1])\overline{\textbf{Span}}^{\|{\cdot}{}\|_{\infty}}\{e^{2\pi i n x}\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} = C([0,1])Span​∥⋅∥∞​{e2πinx}n∈Z​=C([0,1]).
Hence,

Span‾∥⋅∥2{e2πinx}n∈Z=C([0,1])‾∥⋅∥2=L2([0,1]).\overline{\textbf{Span}}^{\|{\cdot}{}\|_{2}}\{e^{2\pi i n x}\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} = \overline{C([0,1])}^{\|{\cdot}{}\|_2} = L^2([0,1]).Span​∥⋅∥2​{e2πinx}n∈Z​=C([0,1])​∥⋅∥2​=L2([0,1]).

{e2πinx}n∈Z\{e^{2\pi i n x}\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}{e2πinx}n∈Z​ is an orthonormal of L2([0,1])L^2([0,1])L2([0,1]), and dim⁡L2([0,1])=ℵ0\dim L^2([0,1]) = \aleph_0dimL2([0,1])=ℵ0​.

entry.title: 一个因子之和的积分表达
entry.content:
定义： 我们用 σ(n)\sigma(n)σ(n) 表示自然数 nnn 的所有因子之和，即

σ(n)=∑m∣nm\sigma(n) = \sum_{m|n}{m}σ(n)=m∣n∑​m

  (1). 若一个自然数 nnn , 做素因数分解：n=p1a1⋅⋅⋅pkakn = p_{1}^{a_1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{k}^{a_k}n=p1a1​​⋅⋅⋅pkak​​, 则有

σ(n)=p1a1+1−1p1−1⋅⋅⋅pkak+1−1pk−1\sigma(n) = \dfrac{p_{1}^{a_1+1} - 1}{p_1 - 1} \cdot\cdot\cdot \dfrac{p_{k}^{a_k+1} - 1}{p_k - 1}σ(n)=p1​−1p1a1​+1​−1​⋅⋅⋅pk​−1pkak​+1​−1​

证明：

  注意到

∏i=1k∑j=0αipij=∑(j1,⋅⋅⋅,jk)∈∏i=1k([0,αi]⋂N)p1j1⋅⋅⋅pkjk\prod_{i=1}^{k} {\sum_{j=0}^{ { {\alpha } _ {i} } } {p_{i}^{j} } } =\sum\limits_{\left( { {j}_{1} },\cdot \cdot \cdot ,{ {j}_{k} } \right)\in \prod_{ i=1 }^{k} {\left( \left[ 0,{ {\alpha }_{i} } \right]\bigcap N \right)} } { p_{1}^{ { {j}_{1} } } \cdot \cdot \cdot p_{k}^{ { {j}_{k} } } }i=1∏k​j=0∑αi​​pij​=(j1​,⋅⋅⋅,jk​)∈∏i=1k​([0,αi​]⋂N)∑​p1j1​​⋅⋅⋅pkjk​​

  而

σ(n)=p1a1+1−1p1−1⋅⋅⋅pkak+1−1pk−1=LHS=PHS=σ(n)\sigma(n) = \frac{p_{1}^{a_1 + 1} - 1}{p_1 - 1} \cdot\cdot\cdot \frac{p_{k}^{a_k+1} - 1}{p_k - 1} = LHS = PHS = \sigma(n)σ(n)=p1​−1p1a1​+1​−1​⋅⋅⋅pk​−1pkak​+1​−1​=LHS=PHS=σ(n)

证毕

  (2). 下面给出 σ(n)\sigma(n)σ(n) 的一个积分表达

σ(n)=∑m=1n∫0mcos⁡2nπ[x+1]mdx\sigma(n) = \sum_{m=1}^{n}\int_{0}^{m}\cos{\dfrac{2n\pi[x+1]}{m}}dxσ(n)=m=1∑n​∫0m​cosm2nπ[x+1]​dx

证明:

  我们考虑求和号里面的式子

  注意到, 利用 Euler 公式, 有

∑k=1mcos⁡2knπm=Re(∑k=1me2nkπim)\sum_{k=1}^{m}\cos{\dfrac{2kn\pi}{m}} = Re\left(\sum_{k=1}^{m}e^{\dfrac{2nk\pi i}{m}}\right)k=1∑m​cosm2knπ​=Re⎝⎜⎜⎛​k=1∑m​em2nkπi​⎠⎟⎟⎞​

  又

∑k=1me2nkπim={e2nmπim−1e2nπim−1=0,m∤nm,m ∣ n\sum_{k=1}^{m}e^{\dfrac{2nk\pi i}{m}} =\left\{\begin{matrix}\dfrac{e^{\dfrac{2nm\pi i}{m}}-1}{e^{\dfrac{2n\pi i}{m}}-1} = 0,\quad m \nmid n\\m, \quad m\ |\ n\end{matrix}\right.k=1∑m​em2nkπi​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​em2nπi​−1em2nmπi​−1​=0,m∤nm,m ∣ n​

  所以，我们得到

∑k=1mcos⁡2knπm=Re(∑k=1me2nkπim)={0,m∤nm,m ∣ n\sum_{k=1}^{m}\cos{\dfrac{2kn\pi}{m}} = Re\left(\sum_{k=1}^{m}e^{\dfrac{2nk\pi i}{m}}\right) =\left\{\begin{matrix}0,\quad m \nmid n\\m, \quad m\ |\ n\end{matrix}\right.k=1∑m​cosm2knπ​=Re⎝⎜⎜⎛​k=1∑m​em2nkπi​⎠⎟⎟⎞​={0,m∤nm,m ∣ n​

  回到原式

RHS=∑m=1n∑k=1mcos⁡2knπm=∑m∣nm=σ(n)=LHSRHS = \sum_{m=1}^{n}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\cos{\dfrac{2kn\pi}{m}} = \sum_{m|n}m = \sigma(n) = LHSRHS=m=1∑n​k=1∑m​cosm2knπ​=m∣n∑​m=σ(n)=LHS

证毕

entry.title: 测度的延拓 - Exterior Measure
entry.content:
首先我们给出一个总的思路：(或者说前提小结，也可以说是摘要)

  我们从集 XXX 的某些子集所成的环 R\mathscr{R}R, 以及环 R\mathscr{R}R 上的测度 μ\muμ 出发. 根据环 R\mathscr{R}R 做集类 H(R)\mathscr{H(R)}H(R), 它是一个 σ−\sigma-σ−环. 然后由测度 μ\muμ, 在 H(R)\mathscr{H(R)}H(R) 上作出由 μ\muμ 引出的外测度 μ∗\mu ^{*}μ∗, μ∗\mu^*μ∗ 是 μ\muμ 的“延拓”, 即对于 ∀E∈R\forall E \in \mathscr{R}∀E∈R, 有 μ∗(E)=μ(E)\mu^*(E)=\mu(E)μ∗(E)=μ(E). 外测度 μ∗\mu^*μ∗ 具有测度的一部分性质, 但不一定有可加性, 一般来说只有次可加性. 但是, 我们可以利用 CaratheodoryCaratheodoryCaratheodory 条件分出了一类集, 即 μ∗−\mu^*-μ∗− 可测集的全体 (R∗⊂H(R))\left(\mathscr{R}^* \subset \mathscr{H(R)} \right)(R∗⊂H(R)), 是一个 σ−\sigma-σ−环. 而且, R\mathscr{R}R 中的元素都是 μ∗−\mu^*-μ∗− 可测集. 如果把外测度限制在 R∗\mathscr{R}^*R∗ 上, 可列可加性成立, 因此 μ∗\mu^*μ∗ 是 R∗\mathscr{R}^*R∗ 上的测度, 而且是完全测度.

定义 1： 设 R\mathscr{R}R 是集 XXX 上的环, 我们定义这样的集：

H(R)={E:E⊂⋃i=1∞Ei,Ei∈R}\mathscr{H(R)} = \left\{ E: E \subset \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}E_i, E_i \in \mathscr{R} \right\}H(R)={E:E⊂i=1⋃∞​Ei​,Ei​∈R}

显然, H(R)⊃R\mathscr{H(R) \supset R}H(R)⊃R 是一个 σ−\sigma-σ−环. H(R)\mathscr{H(R)}H(R) 中的每一个元素都能被 R\mathscr{R}R 中的可列个元素的并覆盖.

定义 2： 设 μ∗\mu^*μ∗ 是定义在 H(R)\mathscr{H(R)}H(R) 上的集函数, μ∗:H(R)→R\mu^*: \mathscr{H(R) \to R}μ∗:H(R)→R :

μ∗(E)=inf⁡{∑i=1∞Ei:E⊂⋃i=1∞Ei,Ei∈R}\mu^*(E) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^{\infty}E_i : E\subset \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}E_i, E_i \in \mathscr{R}\right\}μ∗(E)=inf{i=1∑∞​Ei​:E⊂i=1⋃∞​Ei​,Ei​∈R}

称 μ∗\mu^*μ∗ 为由测度 μ\muμ 诱导出的外测度.

定义 3： (Carathodory条件)(Carathodory\text{条件})(Carathodory条件) 设 E∈R∗E \in \mathscr{R^*}E∈R∗ 及 F∈H(R)F \in \mathscr{H(R)}F∈H(R), 若成立：

μ∗(F)=μ∗(F∩E)+μ∗(F−E)\mu^*(F) = \mu^*(F\cap E) + \mu^*(F-E)μ∗(F)=μ∗(F∩E)+μ∗(F−E)

则称, 集 EEE 满足 Carathodory条件Carathodory\text{条件}Carathodory条件.

定义 4： 设 μ\muμ 是环 R\mathscr{R}R 上的测度, E∈RE \in \mathscr{R}E∈R. 如果有 μ(E)=0\mu(E) = 0μ(E)=0 就称 EEE 是 μ−\mu-μ−零集, 简称零集(零测集). 如果 R\mathscr{R}R 中任何 μ−\mu-μ−零集的任何子集都必定属于环 R\mathscr{R}R, 那么称 μ\muμ 是一个完全测度.

定理 ： μ∗−\mu^*-μ∗− 可测集的全体 R∗\mathscr{R^*}R∗ 是一个 σ−\sigma-σ−环, 并且 μ∗\mu^*μ∗ 是 R∗\mathscr{R^*}R∗ 上的测度.

有一些很重要的证明技巧, 充分利用下确界的定义, 需要掌握

entry.title: Measure on the Ring
entry.content:
Definition 1:

Let XXX is a fixed set(or a Basic Space), and denote E:={E:E⊂X}\mathcal{E} := \left\{ E:E\subset X \right\}E:={E:E⊂X}. Call E\mathcal{E}E is a set class on XXX.

Definition 2:

Let E\mathcal{E}E is a set class on XXX, and if its elements satisfy:

∀E1,E2∈E\forall E_1,E_2 \in \mathcal{E}∀E1​,E2​∈E, have E1∪E2∈EE_1 \cup E_2 \in \mathcal{E}E1​∪E2​∈E and E1−E2∈EE_1-E_2 \in \mathcal{E}E1​−E2​∈E, then we called E\mathcal{E}E is a Ring on XXX and denote: R\mathcal{R}R.

In particular, if we have X∈RX \in \mathcal{R}X∈R, we called R\mathcal{R}R is a σ−\sigma-σ−Ring on XXX.

Definition 3:

Let E\mathcal{E}E is a set class on XXX, and define the mapping from E\mathcal{E}E to XXX:

μ:E→R\mu : \mathcal{E}\to \mathbb{R}μ:E→R

then, called μ\muμ is set function on E\mathcal{E}E.

Definition 4:

Let R\mathcal{R}R is a Ring on XXX, and we define the set function μ:R→R\mu : \mathcal{R}\to \mathbb{R}μ:R→R, and satisfied:

i>. μ(∅)=0\mu (\varnothing) = 0μ(∅)=0

ii>. (Non-negative) ∀E∈R\forall E \in \mathcal{R}∀E∈R, has μ(E)≥0\mu (E) \ge 0μ(E)≥0

iii>.(Additivity) En∈RE_n \in \mathcal{R}En​∈R, n=1,2,...n=1,2,...n=1,2,..., and ∀Ei∩Ej=∅(i≠j)\forall E_i \cap E_j=\varnothing (i \ne j)∀Ei​∩Ej​=∅(i​=j), have:

μ(⋃n=1∞En)=∑n=1∞μ(En)\mu \left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}E_n \right) =\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\mu(E_n)μ(n=1⋃∞​En​)=n=1∑∞​μ(En​)

then, we called μ\muμ is a measure on R\mathcal{R}R.

Theorem

If R\mathcal{R}R is a Ring on XXX, and μ\muμ is a measure on R\mathcal{R}R, then it has:

  i>. (Limited additivity) If E1,E2,...,En∈RE_1,E_2,...,E_n \in \mathcal{R}E1​,E2​,...,En​∈R, and ∀Ei∩Ej=∅(i≠j)\forall E_i \cap E_j=\varnothing (i \ne j)∀Ei​∩Ej​=∅(i​=j),have:

μ(⋃i=1nEn)=∑i=1nμ(En)\mu \left(\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}E_n \right) =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mu(E_n)μ(i=1⋃n​En​)=i=1∑n​μ(En​)

  ii>. (Monotonicity) If E1,E2∈RE_1,E_2 \in \mathcal{R}E1​,E2​∈R, and E1⊂E2E_1\subset E_2E1​⊂E2​, then

μ(E1)≤μ(E2)\mu(E_1) \le \mu(E_2)μ(E1​)≤μ(E2​)

  iii>. (Reducibility) If E1,E2∈RE_1,E_2 \in \mathcal{R}E1​,E2​∈R, E1⊂E2E_1\subset E_2E1​⊂E2​, and μ(E1)≤∞\mu(E_1) \le \inftyμ(E1​)≤∞, then

μ(E2−E1)=μ(E2)−μ(E1)\mu(E_2-E_1)=\mu(E_2)-\mu(E_1)μ(E2​−E1​)=μ(E2​)−μ(E1​)

  iv>. (Secondary additivity) If En,E∈RE_n,E \in \mathcal{R}En​,E∈R, n=1,2,...n=1,2,...n=1,2,..., and E⊂⋃n=1∞EnE\subset \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}E_nE⊂⋃n=1∞​En​, then

μ(E)≤∑n=1∞μ(En)\mu(E) \le \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\mu(E_n)μ(E)≤n=1∑∞​μ(En​)

  v>. If En∈RE_n \in \mathcal{R}En​∈R, , E1⊂E2⊂⋅⋅⋅,E_1\subset E_2\subset \cdot \cdot \cdot ,E1​⊂E2​⊂⋅⋅⋅, and ⋃n=1∞En∈R\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}E_n \in \mathcal{R}⋃n=1∞​En​∈R, then

μ(⋃n=1∞En)=lim⁡n→∞μ(En)\mu \left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}E_n \right) =\lim_{n\to \infty}\mu(E_n)μ(n=1⋃∞​En​)=n→∞lim​μ(En​)

  vi>. If En∈RE_n \in \mathcal{R}En​∈R, , E1⊃E2⊃⋅⋅⋅,E_1\supset E_2\supset \cdot \cdot \cdot ,E1​⊃E2​⊃⋅⋅⋅, ⋂n=1∞En∈R\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}E_n \in \mathcal{R}⋂n=1∞​En​∈R, and ∃En\exists E_n∃En​ such that μ(Em)<∞\mu(E_m) < \inftyμ(Em​)<∞, then

μ(⋂n=1∞En)=lim⁡n→∞μ(En)\mu \left(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}E_n \right) =\lim_{n\to \infty}\mu(E_n)μ(n=1⋂∞​En​)=n→∞lim​μ(En​)

In addition, if R\mathcal{R}R is a σ-Ring\sigma \text{-Ring}σ-Ring, we have:

  vii>. If En∈RE_n \in \mathcal{R}En​∈R, , then

μ(lim⁡inf⁡nEn)≤lim⁡inf⁡nμ(En)\mu\left(\lim\inf_{n}E_n\right) \le \lim\inf_{n}\mu(E_n)μ(limninf​En​)≤limninf​μ(En​)

  viii>. If En∈RE_n \in \mathcal{R}En​∈R, , and ∃k∈N\exists k \in \mathbb{N}∃k∈N, such that ⋃n=k∞En<∞\bigcup_{n=k}^{\infty}E_n < \infty⋃n=k∞​En​<∞, then

μ(lim⁡sup⁡nEn)≥lim⁡sup⁡nμ(En)\mu\left(\lim\sup_{n}E_n\right) \ge \lim\sup_{n}\mu(E_n)μ(limnsup​En​)≥limnsup​μ(En​)

  ix>. If En∈RE_n \in \mathcal{R}En​∈R, , lim⁡En\lim E_nlimEn​ exists and ∃k∈N\exists k \in \mathbb{N}∃k∈N such that ⋃n=k∞En<∞\bigcup_{n=k}^{\infty}E_n < \infty⋃n=k∞​En​<∞, then

μ(lim⁡n→∞En)=lim⁡n→∞μ(En)\mu\left(\lim_{n\to \infty}E_n\right) = \lim_{n\to \infty}\mu(E_n)μ(n→∞lim​En​)=n→∞lim​μ(En​)

  x. If En∈RE_n \in \mathcal{R}En​∈R, , and ∃k∈N\exists k \in \mathbb{N}∃k∈N such that ∑n=k∞μ(En)<∞\sum_{n=k}^{\infty}\mu(E_n) < \infty∑n=k∞​μ(En​)<∞, then

μ(lim⁡sup⁡nEn)=0\mu\left(\lim\sup_{n}E_n\right) = 0μ(limnsup​En​)=0

entry.title: Two problems of Chapter 2
entry.content:
Fourier Analysis

Problem 1

  One can construct Riemann integrable functions on [0,1][0,1][0,1] that have a dense set of discontinuities as follows.

 (a) Let f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0, when x<0x<0x<0, and f(x)=1f(x)=1f(x)=1 if x≥0x\geq0x≥0. Choose a countable dense sequence {rn}\{r_n\}{rn​} in [0,1][0,1][0,1]. Then, show that function

F(x)=∑n=1∞1n2f(x−rn)F(x)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \dfrac{1}{n^2} f(x-r_n)F(x)=n=1∑∞​n21​f(x−rn​)

is integrable and has discontinuities at all points of the sequence {rn}\{r_n\}{rn​}

Proof:

 Step one: Note that F(x)F(x)F(x) is monotonic and bounded for the definition of fff,and F(x)≤F(x) \leqF(x)≤ Euler’s series, so that it has countable discontinuities at most. Hence, F(x)F(x)F(x) is integrable on [0,1][0,1][0,1].

  Step two: We consider that F(rn)F(r_n)F(rn​). {rn}\{r_n\}{rn​} is dense in [0,1][0,1][0,1] means ∀ε>0,\forall \varepsilon >0,∀ε>0, , ∃n∈N\exists n \in \mathbb{N}∃n∈N such that ∣x−rn∣<ε|x-r_n|<\varepsilon∣x−rn​∣<ε. Or ∀x1,x2∈[0,1]\forall x_1,x_2 \in [0,1]∀x1​,x2​∈[0,1], ∃n∈N\exists n \in \mathbb{N}∃n∈N such that rnr_nrn​ is between x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​. Fixed x2=rnx_2 = r_nx2​=rn​, n=1,2,3,...n=1,2,3,...n=1,2,3,... and consider that:

∣F(x)−F(rn)∣|F(x)-F(r_n)|∣F(x)−F(rn​)∣

∀δ>0\forall \delta > 0∀δ>0, when ∣x−rn∣<δ|x-r_n| < \delta∣x−rn​∣<δ, we can find rmr_mrm​ is between xxx and rnr_nrn​. Due to F(x)F(x)F(x) is monotonic, we have

Where Cn,mC_{n,m}Cn,m​ is a constant(If we fix mmm and nnn). That is F(x)F(x)F(x) is discontinuous at all points x=rnx=r_nx=rn​.

(#)(\#)(#)

  (b)Consider next

F(x)=∑n=1∞3−ng(x−rn)F(x)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} 3^{-n}g(x-r_n)F(x)=n=1∑∞​3−ng(x−rn​)

where g(x)=sin⁡1xg(x)=\sin{\dfrac{1}{x}}g(x)=sinx1​ when x≠0x\neq0x​=0, and g(0)=0g(0)=0g(0)=0. Then FFF is integrable, discontinuous at each x=rnx=r_nx=rn​, and fails to be monotonic in any subinterval of [0,1][0,1][0,1].

Proof:

  Note that g(x)g(x)g(x) is bounded, and the geometric series ∑3−n\sum 3^{-n}∑3−n is convergence. So F(x)F(x)F(x) is bounded.

Next, we discuss the integrability of F(x)F(x)F(x). Denote

U=∑j=1N[sup⁡xj−1≤x≤xj{∑n=1∞3−ng(x−rn)}](xj−xj−1)\mathcal{U}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\left[\sup_{x_{j-1} \leq x \leq x_j}\left\{\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} 3^{-n}g(x-r_n)\right\}\right](x_j-x_{j-1})}U=j=1∑N​[xj−1​≤x≤xj​sup​{n=1∑∞​3−ng(x−rn​)}](xj​−xj−1​)

L=∑j=1N[inf⁡xj−1≤x≤xj{∑n=1∞3−ng(x−rn)}](xj−xj−1)\mathcal{L}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\left[\inf_{x_{j-1} \leq x \leq x_j}\left\{\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} 3^{-n}g(x-r_n)\right\}\right](x_j-x_{j-1})}L=j=1∑N​[xj−1​≤x≤xj​inf​{n=1∑∞​3−ng(x−rn​)}](xj​−xj−1​)

Then,

U−L=∑j=1Nωj(x)(xj−xj−1)\mathcal{U-L}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\omega_j(x)(x_j-x_{j-1})}U−L=j=1∑N​ωj​(x)(xj​−xj−1​)

Where

So, we prove that there is at most countable ωj(x)>0\omega_j(x) > 0ωj​(x)>0 as N→∞N\to \inftyN→∞.

 © The original example of Riemann is the function

F(x)=∑n=1∞(nx)n2F(x)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \dfrac{(nx)}{n^2}F(x)=n=1∑∞​n2(nx)​

where (x)=x(x)=x(x)=x for x∈(−12,12]x \in (-\dfrac{1}{2},\dfrac{1}{2}]x∈(−21​,21​], and (x)(x)(x) is continued to R\mathbb{R}R by periodicity, that is, (x+1)=(x)(x+1)=(x)(x+1)=(x). It can be shown that FFF is discontinuous whenever x=m2nx=\dfrac{m}{2n}x=2nm​, where m,n∈Zm,n\in \mathbb{Z}m,n∈Z with mmm odd and n≠0n \neq 0n​=0.

Proof:

Problem 2

  Let DND_NDN​ denote the Dirichlet kernel

DN(θ)=∑k=−NNeikθ=sin⁡(N+12θ)sin⁡θ2D_N(\theta)=\sum_{k=-N}^{N}e^{ik\theta}=\dfrac{\sin\left(N+\dfrac{1}{2} \theta\right)}{\sin\dfrac{\theta}{2}}DN​(θ)=k=−N∑N​eikθ=sin2θ​sin(N+21​θ)​

and define

LN=12π∫−ππ∣DN(θ)∣dθL_N=\dfrac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\left|D_N(\theta)\right|d\thetaLN​=2π1​∫−ππ​∣DN​(θ)∣dθ

  (a)Prove that

LN≥clog⁡NL_N \geq c\log NLN​≥clogN

for some constant c>0c>0c>0.

  We calculate LNL_NLN​ straitly:

The last inequality is used Euler’s formula

∑k=1n1k=log⁡n+γn\sum_{k=1}^{n}{\dfrac{1}{k}}=\log n + \gamma_nk=1∑n​k1​=logn+γn​

Where γn\gamma_nγn​ is Euler constant.

  A more careful estimate gives

LN≥4π2log⁡N+O(1)L_N \ge \dfrac{4}{\pi^2} \log N +O(1)LN​≥π24​logN+O(1)

entry.title: 常微分方程解的存在唯一性定理
entry.content:
皮卡存在唯一性定理

1. 定义：

LipschitzLipschitzLipschitz 条件：

 设f(x)f(x)f(x)是定义在R{\mathbb{R}}R上的连续函数，若∀x1,x2∈R\forall x_1 , x_2 \in {\mathbb{R}}∀x1​,x2​∈R，都存在LLL,使得：

∣f(x1)−f(x2)∣≤L∣x1−x2∣|f(x_1)-f(x_2)| \leq L|x_1 - x_2|∣f(x1​)−f(x2​)∣≤L∣x1​−x2​∣

则称f(x)f(x)f(x)在R{\mathbb{R}}R上满足LipschitzLipschitzLipschitz条件

2. 定理内容

 设初值问题：

(E):dydx=f(x,y),y(x0)=y0(E):\quad\dfrac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=f(x,y),\quad y(x_0)=y_0(E):dxdy​=f(x,y),y(x0​)=y0​

其中f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y)在矩形区域：

∣x−x0∣≤a,∣y−y0∣≤b|x-x_0| \leq a ,\quad |y-y_0| \leq b∣x−x0​∣≤a,∣y−y0​∣≤b

内连续，且对yyy满足LipschitzLipschitzLipschitz条件.则(E)(E)(E)在区间I=[x0−h,x0+h]I=[x_0-h,x_0+h]I=[x0​−h,x0​+h]上有且仅有一个解，其中常数

h=min{a,bM},而M>max⁡(x,y)∈R∣f(x,y)∣h=\mathrm{min}\{a,\dfrac{b}{M}\},而M>\max_{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}}{|f(x,y)|}h=min{a,Mb​},而M>(x,y)∈Rmax​∣f(x,y)∣
